CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

1. POBDTPD and PEBDTPD: These are the names of the two new donor-acceptor type low band gap polymers developed in the study.
2. Dialkoxybenzodithiophene (BDT): This is the name of the donor moiety used in the synthesis of the polymers.
3. N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD): This is the name of the acceptor moiety used in the synthesis of the polymers.
4. PC 70 BM: This is the name of the electron acceptor fullerene derivative used in the fabrication of the solar cell devices.
5. ITO, PEDOT : PSS, TiO2, and Al: These are the names of the materials used in the fabrication of the solar cell devices.
6. 1-4, [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester (PC 60 BM) and [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester (PC 70 BM): These are the names of two common electron acceptor fullerene derivatives used in the field of polymer solar cells.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. POBDTPD and PEBDTPD: These are the names of the two new low band gap polymers developed in the study.
2. Dialkoxybenzodithiophene (BDT): This is the name of the donor moiety used in the synthesis of the polymers.
3. N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione (DTPD): This is the name of the acceptor moiety used in the synthesis of the polymers.
4. PC 70 BM: This is the name of the electron acceptor fullerene derivative used in the fabrication of the solar cell devices.

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| --- |
| POBDTPD |
| PEBDTPD |

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: We report the synthesis , characterization , and solar cell properties of new donor - acceptor - type low band gap polymers ( POBDTPD and PEBDTPD ) that incorporate dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5-azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The newly developed DTPD moiety was carefully designed to lower a band gap via strong interaction between donor - acceptor moieties and keep polymer energy levels deep. Remarkably , the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively widens the light absorption range of the polymers up to ∼ 900 nm while positioning their HOMO and LUMO levels in the optimal range , i.e. , -5.3 and -4.0 eV , respectively , for high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as we intended. Solar cell devices were fabricated according to the structure ITO / PEDOT : PSS / photoactive ( polymer : PC 70 BM ) / TiO 2 / Al. The POBDTPD devices exhibited a PCE of 4.7% with a V oc of 0.70 V , a J sc of 10.6 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.64. The PEBDTPD devices yielded a higher PCE of 5.3% with a V oc of 0.72 V , a J sc of 13.5 mA / cm^2 , and a FF of 0.54. AFM , TEM , and PL quenching measurements revealed that the high J sc s are a result of the appropriate morphology and efficient charge separation. In comparing the performances of the two polymer devices , the higher J sc for the PEBDTPD device was attributed to its better nanoscale phase separation , smoother surface , and higher carrier mobility in the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films. The higher FF for the POBDTPD device was ascribed to a good balance between the hole and electron mobilities. Overall , we demonstrate that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - accepting moiety to develop high performance low band gap polymers . Polymer solar cells ( PSCs ) have attracted great attention for their potential utility in the production of large - area , low - cost , and flexible photovoltaic devices via solution processing. 1-4 To achieve high power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) , electrondonor polymers should have the following desirable characteristics : ( i ) good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum , ( ii ) optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron - acceptor fullerene derivatives ( typically [6,6]-phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 60 BM ) or [6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester ( PC 70 BM ) ) to facilitate efficient exciton separation , ( iii ) formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer , and ( iv ) provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes. To meet these requirements , intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating electron - rich donor units and electron - deficient acceptor units into a single conjugated polymeric system.

Let's think step by step.

1. Energy levels of HOMO (Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital) and LUMO (Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital) for POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers:
- HOMO level for POBDTPD: -5.3 eV
- LUMO level for POBDTPD: -4.0 eV
- HOMO level for PEBDTPD: Not explicitly stated, but assumed to be similar to POBDTPD since the acceptor moiety is the main factor affecting the LUMO level
- LUMO level for PEBDTPD: -4.0 eV + energy level shift due to the DTPD acceptor

2. Solar cell device parameters for POBDTPD and PEBDTPD:
- Voc (Open Circuit Voltage) for POBDTPD: 0.70 V
- Jsc (Short Circuit Current Density) for POBDTPD: 10.6 mA/cm^2
- FF (Fill Factor) for POBDTPD: 0.64
- Voc for PEBDTPD: 0.72 V
- Jsc for PEBDTPD: 13.5 mA/cm^2
- FF for PEBDTPD: 0.54

3. Solar cell device structure:
- ITO (Indium Tin Oxide)
- PEDOT: PSS (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene):poly(styrenesulfonate))
- Photoactive layer: Polymer (POBDTPD or PEBDTPD) : PC 70 BM ([6,6]-phenyl-C71butyric acid methyl ester)
- TiO2
- Al (Aluminum)

4. Desirable characteristics for high power conversion efficiencies in polymer solar cells:
- Good absorption spectral overlap with the solar spectrum
- Optimal energy level alignment with respect to electron acceptor fullerene derivatives (PC 60 BM or PC 70 BM)
- Formation of a nanoscale interpenetrating network of the polymer and fullerene domains inside the photoactive layer
- Provision of effective charge transport carriers toward the electrodes

5. Electron-rich donor units and electron-deficient acceptor units in a single conjugated polymeric system:
- Intensive research efforts have been focused on integrating these units to meet the requirements for high power conversion efficiencies in polymer solar cells.

No specific numerical values are mentioned for the energy levels of the donor units or the energy level shifts due to the acceptor moieties. However, the text states that the DTPD acceptor moiety effectively lowers the band gap and positions the energy levels in the optimal range for high power conversion efficiencies.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. Energy levels of HOMO and LUMO for POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers:
- HOMO level for POBDTPD: -5.3 eV
- LUMO level for POBDTPD: -4.0 eV
- LUMO level for PEBDTPD: -4.0 eV + energy level shift due to the DTPD acceptor

2. Solar cell device parameters for POBDTPD and PEBDTD:
- Voc (Open Circuit Voltage) for POBDTPD: 0.70 V
- Jsc (Short Circuit Current Density) for POBDTPD: 10.6 mA/cm^2
- FF (Fill Factor) for POBDTPD: 0.64
- Voc for PEBDTPD: 0.72 V
- Jsc for PEBDTPD: 13.5 mA/cm^2
- FF for PEBDTPD: 0.54
